Your statement that bloodletting was a harmful practice is incorrect, or at least incomplete. While bloodletting (therapeutic phlebotomy) was historically misused by some practitioners, it had/has many benefits for the right patient. Phlebotomy is the treatment of choice for hemochromatosis (the most common genetic disease in Europeans). There is reliable evidence that phlebotomy helps reduce fever, joint & muscle pain, headaches, and works well for depression.
It may have additional benefits for congestive heart failure, hypertension, and acute stroke. There is even some evidence that bloodletting was helpful as a treatment for The Plague. The problem with phoebotomy was it’s being overused for inappropriate conditions as a “one size fits all” approach. Using available therapies JUDICIOUSLY was what separated the good physicians from the bad.

The Scientific Method is not just a human practice. We just put a name to it, as well as formalized the process. Other animals (and plants, even!) practice scientific method, although not to determine the orbit of the planet or whether gravitational waves exist. The version of the scientific method they use is more commonly known as trial-and-error: propose a hypothesis (this fruit is edible). Test it out. If animal died immediately, other observant animals will eschew eating that fruit.

From a local perspective here in Iceland I can tell you the following:

Icelandic Viking warriors are said to have taken Lýsi to stay strong, also supposed to prevent you from catching cold, the Greenland vikings vanished during the "Little Ice Age" likely from combination of factors.

The Icelandic currency Króna has a Cod on its front. (Not to be confused with the CCP EVE ISK).

Here in Iceland the product is known as LÝSI and marketed as the "Nations Secret Weapon", sometimes stores have reported how shelfs of Lýsi are bought up when tourists from Asian come to town, they seem to appreaciate this golden liquid too.

Iceland "won" ~3 so called Cod-Wars with Britain over this fish, in some part thanks to the Secret-Weapon "Net-Cutters" and well NATO worried about Communist making the alliance look bad.
Oh Yeah also not the first time one hears the story of a bigger guy trying to take someones elses oil (albe it fish-oil;)"

Also Iceland has a very strict Fish-Management system called the "Kvótakerfið" its been a cause of much debate over the decades as while it helps manage the fish stock very efficiently compared to other places it also has created a type of elite called KvótaKóngar/KvótaGreifar as in QuotaKing/QuotaCount, I guess comparable to the Banker Elite that runs the US ;D

I remember hearing news back in the day where trawlers had their nets confiscated and needing to pay fines coz the fish holes in the net were just 1mm smaller than was allowed, as in making sure nets were up to specs and not catching the smaller fish.

I suppose Iceland manages their fish stock better in part coz its a Island and so it dont have to share much of its fish-stock quota with neighbouring country's which may or may not be upholding a entirely trustworthy fishing management system.

Btw LÝSI can be from shark as well, as in "Hákarlalýsi" which is made from Greenland Shark who is said to be the Longest-Lived Vertebrate on Earth as in older than some countrys like the United States for example, even as old as the re-discovery of Wineland or as you know it today as America though the guys name was Columbus who incidentally thought he was in India, anyway "Leif the Lucky" son of Eric the Red in Greenland discovered it 2x times earlier than Columbus and the Indians were called Skraeling, yeah Lýsi is also supposed to help with good memory like what comes handy for keeping records from long lost times incidentally ;D

One minor linguistic criticism at 6:12. The rule is:
both A and B;
not only A(,) but also B.
Other commonly mixed-up pairings are:
between A and B;
from A to B (A–B = A to B; e.g., Boston–Chicago, 8–9 months);
from one time/hour/period to or till or until another time/hour/period;
either A or B;
neither A nor B.

If the scientific method is "the greatest technology the humans have developed", I think it is a technology of mass destruction. A weapon. That is ending the planet and perhaps will end us all. The scientific method (and those who follow the method like a religious commandant) always tries to disguise itself as a harmless tool. And for all the problems this method has created (mainly climate change), it continues to dominate how we as humans should function and have relations with the natural world for the betterment of the future. But when in fact the scientific method was the cause of all these problems to begin with.

As someone who enjoys science but who is also very aware of the exploitation, mass murder, discrimination that science has allowed to flourish in this world (that is to say, who enjoys science in context), I would argue that perhaps the scientific method which allowed for atrocious events such as the European "crippling" colonialism, Holocausts (of the indigenous peoples, Jewish people and many more minorities that are forgotten) to occur is perhaps the most dangerous weapon humans have developed. This video presents a few interesting theses:
1. Pre/early-historic human civilization north of 42 degrees required a dietary source of vitamin D;
2. memetics and cultural traditions are an effective vector of information transmission and a form of proto-science;
3. viking cultural practices "memetically" promoted consumption of cod for its health effects;
4. vitamin D deficiency is a likely cause of the failure of the viking settlement in Greenland.
5. memetics and cultural traditions are a flawed vector of information transmission;
6. the nautical exploits of the British post 1600 were more successful than those of the vikings because of
availability of citrus fruits on ships (?) or because of cultural patterns better aligned with modern science (?);
7. the scientific method is "the greatest technology humans have ever developed" because it emphasizes mechanisms
of causality and thereby facilitates humans' efforts to design and engineer.
These are all fascinating and reasonable claims. However, they're also complex and deserve thorough treatment. This video doesn't substantiate any of them. Worse, the manner of presentation mostly (not entirely; there are instances of "maybe" and "kind of") conveys a note of conclusiveness not at all warranted.

(At the end of the video, Derek mentions his full-length documentary. I haven't seen it, but I'm guessing it likely addresses some or all of my criticisms. However, if it does, I suppose the two main purposes this video serves are (1) to introduce ideas (but not to elaborate on them) and (2) to advertise Derek's other video. The second seems like the primary goal, and I think Derek should have been more forthright and mentioned that at the beginning of this video. My own opinion anyway.)

Cod liver oil is cool, but this story is a bit sensationalist. You make it sound like the Norse were on the verge of dying out until they discovered glorious cod. In reality Norway has been populated for 10,000 years since the end of the last ice age. Not all of the populations that have lived there in that time have made cod a staple of their diet, especially inland populations.


I'm also not aware of any studies claiming that the Greenland Norse disappeared due to vitamin D deficiency. In fact bone analysis shows that they changed from a predominantly terrestrial diet at the beginning of the settlement (ca 1000) to a predominantly marine-based diet towards the end (15th century). The Norse hunted a lot of seal, which like cod is rich in vitamin D and omega-3 fatty acids, and they made seal oil, which has similar health benefits to cod liver oil. The best explanation put forward so far is that local climate conditions as a result of the Little Ice Age did them in. The Norse diet, by the end of the settlement, was similar to the Inuits who came to Greenland around the same time and are still there to this day. Unlike the Inuit, the Norse depended a lot more on trade with Europe, which became near impossible with harbors frozen nearly year round.

Right, couple of notes from an amateur historian on this otherwise excellent video:

Historians now generally regard the term "Viking" as a verb, rather than a denomyn noun. That is to say it was an activity - the looting, the pillaging, the storming of monasteries, that was "Viking". It became a term attached to the peoples of the Scandinavian peninsula who partook in this activity, although contemporary sources such as the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle don't refer to them as such. You can describe them as Norse if you want to generalise, which refers to their shared religious and cultural practices, or you can refer to them by their individual denomyns, which just happen to correspond perfectly to the modern Nordic countries - Danes, Swedes, Norwegians (or just Norse, which is why it can be incorrect to use Norse to refer to all Scandinavians), and Icelanders/Greenlanders. Scandinavian is also wrong not only because the Norse expanded their cultural reach beyond Scandinavia to places such as England, Ireland (where they founded Dublin), to Ukraine (they founded Kyiv), and yes, to North America, but also because the Sami people of Finland and the Lapps and various other peoples live/d in Scandinavia, and they are NOT Norse because they don't speak a Nordic language, which is a Germanic language family, and because they are a culturally and ethnically distinct peoples.

Second, your point about scurvy. Yes, it greatly contributed to the prosperity of the British colonial empire, but they came to dominate the seas in the late 18th/early 19th century, which is pretty late in the grand scheme of things. They were not the first nation to establish a colonial empire off of the back of naval dominance, they were merely following in the tradition of their contemporaries, which were the French and the Dutch. And of course the first great colonial empires were established by Spain and Portugal, and the Spanish Empire controlled most of the continental Americas and monopolised Trans-Atlantic trade hundreds of years before the days when one could say that the sun never set on the British Empire. It would therefore be naive to assume that they didn't benefit from the knowledge of the world and of maritime practices that were learnt and developed by the Portuguese, the Spanish, and the Dutch.

And last point, most of the early English colonial endeavours were massive failures. Their colony in Roanoke, the first in the modern United States, vanished without a trace; the Jamestown colony never turned a profit for its shareholders which is what it was designed to do; and they lagged well behind France and Spain when it came to capitalising on the insanely lucrative sugar trade in the Caribbean (which the Portuguese didn't need to muscle in on because they had their own profitable sugar colonies in Brazil).

This video is very substandard for the expectations I have of Veritasum. Why? Let's see:

(1) Only cod provides vitamin D? No! All fish and seafood does, cod would be as good in general terms as herring or haddock or even lobster.

(2) Vitamin D deficiency's only consequence is rickets? That would be 20th century level of knowledge, however in our time we have learned it has many other roles, some of them maybe even mor important that bone formation: neuronal development particularly, but also urinary system, allergies, psoriasis, etc. Vitamin D is of the essence, very especially for children and it has only two sources: the sun (via the skin, as you described) and fish/seafood.

(3) Vitamin D deficiency has driven the skin color selection (evolution of depigmentation). I wouldn't expect you to know everything on this matter but at least a mention, what less?!

(4) What the heck that mention to scurvy and fruits in the end? It's not even related to vitamin D (scurvy is caused by lack of vitamin C). Probably Britain is worth a mention re. vitamin D deficiency, because evidence shows that since the first Neolithic to the Viking era, almost no fish was consumed in the island, what is a perfect recipy for all the ills of vitamin D deficiency... and lighter color skin selection. It probably did not happen only in Britain but that's a place that is well researched in this regard.

It's not just citrus fruits that cure scurvy - malt, wort, and vinegar were also found to be effective. Vinegar was especially useful on ships, as foods like sauerkraut can be preserved in vinegar.

As a side note, on his first voyage of discovery, James Cook insisted on his officers eating "sour crout" (sic) in a successful attempt to induce the crew to do likewise, although he thought the wort and malt were more effective. Citrus fruits weren't listed as being on the Endeavour (likely as they would spoil quickly in the humid shipboard environment), although frequent restocking of fresh food and greenstuffs along the voyage certainly helped with the crew's continuing health. And he didn't lose a single seaman to scurvy - previous to this, George Anson, in his voyage of 1740, lost nearly two-thirds of his crew (1,300 out of 2,000) within the first 10 months, mostly to scurvy.

It's not that there wasn't cod off Greenland. The Inuit (or the prior occupants of the Arctic of North America, I don't remember offhand what they were called) were there too, and still are. They posed a significant hostile neighbor factor (as the Norse tended to stab them when they interacted, and called them Skraelings) that played as large a role in the Greenland Norse collapse as vitamin D deficiency. The Inuit established themselves farther north, where the walrus were that the Norse hunted for trade with their homeland.  That was a source of conflict.      There was also the Little Ice Age. That slowed and eventually eliminated supplies coming from Scandinavia. There were also substantial agricultural issues pertaining to the volcanic origin of the soil. When the Norse arrived, the outward appearance was not dissimilar to their homeland, but it was actually much more fragile, and responded disasterously to European-style agriculture. There is also some evidence that Eric the Red may have become seriously ill after eating fish in Greenland, and as the leader, decreed that fish were evil, and the Inuit that were eating it were demonic. But that's not proven.       It weren't just the fish. It were many factors.

The "scurvy is why Britain was the major naval power" hypothesis doesn't stack up. Lind's 1747 study that's mentioned here was pretty much ignored by the naval and medical establishment. As late as the 1790's the preferred supplements were wort and malt (byproducts of the brewing industry) and dilute sulfuric acid(!).

Lemons were standard by 1800 which worked but were gradually replaced by lime juice stored in copper containers which contains almost no Vitamin C. It didn't really matter by then because steamships had arrived and most voyages were shorter than the time it takes to develop scurvy.

Other countries were also experimenting with dietary supplements as well. Britain had the most powerful navy in the C19 for all kinds of reasons but they aren't citrus fruit related. The science around lemons and scurvy stayed very confused until the C20.

A common problem with cultural knowledge is that it solves a given problem but does not record what the problem is, so when the problems change, the culture becomes a misfit. This is a major problem in the modern age when so much has changed that many cultural solutions are solutions to problems no longer in existence. And this is separate from the problem that many cultural practices are specifically designed to promote certain ideologies that may be only beneficial to a particular subset of people.
